critique: This document primarily concerns the delegation of authority regarding arms exports. It doesn't directly address issues of ideological tilt, immigration, civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion. It mainly shifts responsibilities between different departments (State, Defense, Treasury, Commerce) under the existing framework of the Arms Export Control Act. The delegation of power could be seen as a slight expansion of executive power, but it's more about efficient management than a fundamental change in authority. The document doesn't seem to strongly favor either federal or state control, as it operates within the existing federal structure.
